content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												The best F1 game in a long time. F1 2013's Classic mode was pretty good, then they dropped the ball for 14 and 15, but now at last they seem to have gotten things together with their year long dev cycle.Practice sessions now have a purpose with R&D points awarded for various actions, most of which are the challenges or "minigames", the best of which is the track acclimitation which helps you learn the track for the first time. I found myself spending as much time practicing the track as I did racing on it.Safety cars (real and virtual), Formation laps and manual pit entry are also all great new features.Graphics are good, finally looks "next gen" compared to previous years. (Just don't look too hard at people's faces, but who cares your here for the cars/tracks).Oh yeah, and you can actually talk to your radio engineer with your microphone, asking important things like tyre or fuel information, who's infront of you and what their pace is... or just tell him to shut up :D

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												This is my first F1 game since 2013 and I'm not disappointed. The new cars really do feel different and you can feel the torque they all talk about :) The graphics are great, though I haven't seen them in all their glory with a race in the wet. All the tracks so far look awesome, with a lot of detail. Sound is perfect and lower revs make for a much more enjoyable experience with the volume up.They have obviously put some love into this game and not just rehashed an older version, so far I like little touches like your lap time being read back to you.Anyway, back to it.Edit: I've fallen in love with it. I'm running it at max at 2715 x 1527 and the tracks look amazing. The handling is awesome too, I hate it when people think games are not sims unless you're spinning it every two seconds, driving isn't that hard, so a simulation of it shouldn't be. You can really spice this up though by simply removing antilock brakes and it adds a lot when you lock up like a pro.I particulally like the Time Trial set up with your next rivals ghost instantly loading as you beat one and it's fun to think that people will be racing yours.Thoroughly recommend it 10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												Pros:+ Career Mode: Back to the series, and better than ever, career mode is pretty detailed, customizable and fun. I hope Codemasters had learned the lesson with F1 2015 and never fail to invest in a career mode.+ Research and Development: the best R&D mode of the whole series. Performed during training sessions, the challenges are fun and challenging, and teach you how to conserve tires, fuel and understand the track.+ Difficulty levels: With 8 levels of difficulty, and several customizable help systems, the game allows the players to maintain a challenge level perfectly compatible with their abilities.+ G27: Perfect compatibility with the Logitech G27.Cons:- Graphics: Very very bad. Codemasters continues to recycle the same graphics engine since 2010. The game looks like a 2013 game at most. With bad textures, terrible shadow effects, reflection and water, the game disappoints a lot in that aspect. The optimization is reasonable on the track, however in the garage it's awful, and it drops below 40 fps on a GTX970 + i7.- System of rivalry: During the career mode the game always keeps you with an active rivalry, without any use. You earn nothing after winning the rivalry, and immediately a new rival is announced, and sometimes it is the same rival already defeated!- Control in the rain: it may be my lack of ability, but I continue with extreme difficulty in running in the rain. The lack of grip does not seem realistic to me. We do not see the F1 cars sliding all the time in the real races.- Accidents: the most annoying aspect of the game. It remains the same F1 2015 problem, which opponents touch you in the back as if you did not exist! And in ALL the touches, including the small ones , you are always the disadvantaged. Your car will fly off the track and opponents do not move 1 cm. Frustrating!Verdict: With a new customizable and full career mode, fun R&D mode and adjustable difficulty, the game remains fun for dozens of hours. Despite the dated graphics and flaws in collision mechanics and control in the rain, the game can be considered the best of the whole series.Score: 8.5/10

												For me the first night playing this game has been a flawless launch-n-play no non-sense just drive experience.My Xbox 360 controller got detected automatically with the normal button mapping. The controls are great with a gamepad; The car feels heavy and grounded. And it looks great at Medium settings.UPDATE:Game is 500% better after disabling all voice acting.

												Taking the superb handling simulation from F1 2015 and bringing back everything F1 2015 lacked (such as career mode, safety car...), F1 2016 is quite simply the best F1 simulation on the market right now. The visuals, while not quite as nice as Project CARS', are still among the best to be found on any current generation game, and definitely the best seen yet in any F1 game (and with no ugly filters like F1 2015's chromatic aberration and blurry soft focus filtering, visuals here are crystal clear).What Project CARS is to track racing simulators in general, what DIRT Rally is to rally simulators, that's what F1 2016 is to F1 simulators. And that's one of the best endorsments anyone can give to a racing game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												This is my indepth review of F1 2016, sorry for the length but enjoy reading!!F1 2016 adds depth to that detail, its career mode returning after a year's absence more fully featured and less fussy than before. From the outset you're free to sign up with any team on the grid, electing to help push Manor that little bit further up the grid or maintain Mercedes' stronghold on the top steps of the podium. Within that, there are now some neat new kinks.The UI is busy, but necessarily so - there's a lot of data to convey, and unlike previous entries it's now possible to read a race from one single screen.Perhaps F1 2016's greatest achievement is how it's managed to make practice sessions meaningful - something that's eluded many racing games before it. Sit in your cockpit in one of the three practice sessions that precede a race - all set at the correct time of day, so you'll be able to see the Singapore street circuit in a low evening sun before the floodlights kick in - and you're able to select a number of practice programmes, the successful completion of which will net you resource points you can then spend on improving the car.The programmes themselves are mini-games that don't feel out of place amidst F1 2016's quest for realism. Simulate a qualifying run by hitting a set time over three laps; acclimatise to the track by hitting gates that mark out the entry, apex and exit point of each corner; take a set of boots and prove you can tread gently in three laps of tyre management. F1 2016 could certainly benefit from a little more variety in the tasks it gives you in these sessions, but Codemasters has succeeded in injecting purpose in a race weekend outside of what happens on Sunday afternoon once the lights are out.Outside the races themselves there's some slim but effective extras: the virtual paddock from F1 2010 returns, complete with a roster of familiar faces (Eric Boullier! Toto the Wolf! Maurizio "I'd kill to look like you when I'm 60" Arrivabene!), and it's here you can keep tab on contract offers, how you're faring against your team mate, and other rivalries that crop up over the course of a season. F1 2016 generally does a better job of immersing you in the wider world of F1, from the cutaways before each race that take in the bustle of the grid to the post-race formalities. Codemasters' engine might struggle to render flesh and bone the way it does carbon fibre and steel - witness the sallow-skinned, dead-eyed horror of many of its character models - but the effort is appreciated all the same.When all of F1 2016's elements work together, it can make for some real magic. Take one particular race early on in my own campaign. A downpour before the lights in Shanghai leading to a sodden track (one area where F1 2016 deviates from the real thing, thankfully, is that Charlie Whiting's not on hand to make sure you can't have some fun in the rain), with the first 8 laps taking place in treacherous conditions before the skies brighten. As lightening burns its way into the track it's a game of nerves, waiting for someone to blink until Sergio Perez is the first onto intermediates, a notification popping up that he's just set the fastest lap by some margin kick-starting a mad dash for the pits. Lose yourself to it and you can easily convince yourself this is the best F1 game on console in an age.There are still faults to be found. The AI sometimes makes some funky calls - with two laps to go of one race and running in second place well clear of any competitors I was told switching over to a third tyre compound would be the optimum strategy at that point, an offer I politely declined - and it's still an F1 game that's complete with all the limitations and restrictions that particular licence implies. If you've any love for the sport, however, F1 2016 can be exquisite stuff. So intoxicating have I found its take on the sport that for me this isn't just Codemasters' most accomplished F1 game to date - it's the developer's best take on circuit racing since the heady days of the TOCA series.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												One of the best AAA launches I have experienced over the past few years. And certainly the best, most comprehensive F1 game I have played (since 2012), if not THE BEST ever.I will update the review with more hours put in, but as of now, here are my early impressions.Pros - 1. Superb presentation - cosmetic elements, "character" etc in the career mode brings life to the single player gameplay, something a lot of simulators ignore now-a-days.2. Still early days, but I have faced zero technical issues, no stuttering or FPS drops, no crashes, no bugs or glitches. A refereshingly stable AAA release as far as I am concerned. (Win 10, 6700K, Strix 1070, 32GB)3. Plethora of settings to tweak realism, assists, controls and difficulty - lets you enjoy the game exactly how you want. Again, something that is lacking in most indie or AAA games these days.4. Codemasters have been listening to their players. This game is choke-ful of community requested features that multiply the feeling of authenticity of the F1 experience it offers.5. Gorgeous yet un-demanding graphics.6. I am no expert when it comes to handling / physics etc. Sold my G27 for a XBONE controller sometime ago to save space. However I am having lot of fun driving in this game, more so than 2013 - 2015, which is all that matters to me.Cons -1. So far, the only thing I find lacking is car sounds. I have no idea if the current car audio is "realistic" or not, since I have never driven an actual open-wheel car. But for a videogame, the audio can be much more impressive. The ambient sounds are perfect though._______In conclusion, F1 2016 seems like the culmination of years of development of this series. A near-perfect F1 / Racing game. Well done Codemasters.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												I've been playing this series for many years and I have to say they got a lot of things right this time.  The cars are fun to drive, and the AI seems pretty challenging for all types of drivers.  The tracks are great, and thank goodness Germany is back in the mix!  The enhanced menu for making changes to the car while driving is GREAT.For the most fun, career is the way to go.  My only complaints about career mode are 1. The tedious repetition of the laptop, phone calls, and challengers (we should be able to pick our rivals with more XP given for more difficult rivals) 2. There is no bonus R&D given for winning the championship !?!The game is fun, I use the XBOX 360 controller and it seems to work well.All in all, this is the one F1 game I would recommend to anyone looking for a fun racing game ***If you have a very powerful computer***

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												Although the past couple of years left a bitter taste, I decided to take a leap of faith and get the F1 2016 game on pre-purchase offer and it was a good decisionI've only played 5 hours of the game and the impressions are so much better than 2014/2015 versions.Here are the things I most enjoyed during this short amount of time:The career mode is what makes it all fun, choose a low-end team and race your way to the top;Personalize your driver by choosing name, looks, nationality and obviously an Ayrton Senna like helmet;You can develop the car (R&D) along the practice seasons by completing some goals that will also help you to drive better;Control your entire career through your laptop;Beating your teammate is always rewarding;Get the best out of your car at the start of the race by feeding the throttle and releasing the clutch at the exact moment;Watch the pre-race and post-race actions.There are some downsides also:The AI keeps hammering your rear wing under braking, so annoying;There is still lots of wheel spin making it too arcade;After the rain, the track starts to dry slowly and naturally but then hits a turning point where it gets completely dry out of the blue and it is hard to define which strategy to follow.The FFB could be improved, the loose center is still there when using a G27 for example.Overall, it is a good game and in one weekend, I've already played it much more than the previous two versions.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												So far I've only done two 25% races at Australia. But so far things are looking good.I've been a little critical of Codies F1 games in the past. The reason for this is I'm a huge Geoff Crammond fan and always felt that Codemasters F1 games were a bit lacking compared to the Grand Prix series of games. Sure, they've always had better presentation than Crammond's Grand Prix series, but the driving just wasn't there. Sometimes it felt like the car wasn't even connected to the track. On top of this we had a very poor AI system.Starting with f1 2015 I felt that the handling model in Codies F1 games was starting to find it's sweet spot. It's not what I'd think of as "realistic" but it's got a nice balance. F1 2016 improves upon it. It's a much more pleasurable thing to drive now, and the car feels less like you're driving a bus. Couple this with an excellent career mode, better AI and new features like a slightly more advanced damage model and you have a very, very good F1 game.I liked it so much that I bought it on PC and PS4.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												An excellent addition to the F1 series by Codemasters. The last one I played was 2013, and having read the reviews for '14 & '15 I was glad to have missed them out. Short review: I would highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of racing sims in general, and obviously to those who like motorsports. This is the game we've all been waiting for.What immediately strikes you as you jump into Career Mode is the amazing feel of the cars and the sense of detail within the simulation. The set up of the car, in combination with the tyres, temperature, fuel weight and engine setting all play a significant factor on how the car performs. It can be a little daunting at first, but in practice there are three 'practice programs' that help you learn the tracks, and how to conserve your tyres, and what sort of times you'll need to achieve in qualifying. These programs continue to be of use even for those who master the car and track as they provide R&D points which can be used to upgrade the car as the season goes on. As such, as your season progresses, other teams may catch up with you, or you may leave them behind, and the likes of Mercedes are not guaranteed to dominate season after season.The races themselves are fantastic: the AI, whilst not perfect, provides an enjoyable, consistent challenge. It's certainly the most lifelike AI I've ever seen in a racing game. I've seen three cars attack corners at the same time, all exchanging positions, and I've been overtaken through late breaking etc. The AI can sometimes be a bit timid and give you too much space on lower difficulties - but once you start playing on expert, the AI really does provide an almost human like challenge. The biggest issue with the AI is that the jump up to the next difficulty can feel a little too much at times. This means that you might find yourself overachieving on one difficulty setting, but really struggling on the next difficulty up. The implementation of sliders would greatly help with this problem, but it is unlikely that we'll see such a system any time soon.By putting the damage setting to 'simulation' you'll witness fairly frequent (virtual) safety cars. In my last race in Canada there was two SCs following two crashes on T1 and T2 of the first lap, as well as for a mechanical failure late in the race. The SCs helped me conserve my tyres, so I was able to use a 1-stop strategy, which helped me finish in 3rd with a Renault, whilst my teammate got 5th. Other races haven't quite gone so well: at Monaco a rainy start called for intermediate tyres, but I was too quick to jump to slicks when the track dried and I lost quite a bit of time, finishing outside the points. Basically, anything can happen in a race: good fortune or bad luck, so you'll find yourself doing well some races but poorly in others - and the AI likewise struggles and benefits from certain conditions. This makes career mode far more enjoyable, since it's unpredictable and realistic, making the game very replayable.The graphics are very nice - not had any trouble with them following a couple of patches and updating drivers. This isn't an area of the game I'm usually too fussy about, but you can really see the effort Codemasters have made with the game, and it really does enhance the experience. I would say, however, that the sound of the game could do with some work. Bugs have made the sound a bit wonky at times, and the levels are not quite right, especially when passing other cars who are in the pits. Codemasters have already patched many bugs and addressed most issues, so I'm fairly confident that these issues will no longer be relevant in a few months time. In addition to career mode there is custom championships and time trial, although I haven't touch either game mode yet. There is obviously multiplayer - but I've never enjoyed racing games online, so again can't comment on that. To round this off I would say this is the best F1 game yet, it has fantastic replayability, graphics and gameplay. The simulation is the best it's ever been, and the practice programs are extremely useful tools for teaching people the tracks and how to drive quickly and smoothly. Whilst the difficulty settings could do with some tweaking and a few bugs in the sound department ironed out, this game is undoubtedly the new benchmark for the F1 series and is as good as a game we could have wished for.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												F1 2016 is easily the best edition in the Codemasters F1 series that keeps pulling me back in to keep racing the way the previous titles couldn't. I mainly play sports career games, so a big welcome return in the player career mode where you can race as yourself amongst the field that was missing from 2015. The game allows you to somewhat design your own helmet, pick a number that isn't taken by the existing grid and a best-fit driver avatar before picking a team and getting the main game underway. It's obvious this is where Codemasters spent the time this year.Instead of breezing through practice, skipping straight to qualifying like days of old, you are now expected to earn research points via practice programmes that are spent to add updates to your car throughout the season. It is a requirement as the teams around you are continually developing their cars, so you need to too to keep pace. The programmes consist of tyre management, which provides you on tyre wear data for the race as well as research points, track aclimitisation and qualifying runs. They do a great job at making practice interesting and giving you tasks to do during practice helps with the immersiveness of the career.On a gameplay side, Codemasters have done a good job at portraying each car's strength, with the difference between say the Mercedes and Manor noticable, but not blindingly obvious. The handling of the cars feels good and overall the driving is solid. I found this not to be the case on a controller though, with the gamepad just not providing enough responsiveness to race quickly or competitively. It is good to see the safety car return too, this time fully controllable unlike previous versions as well as the new virtual safety car. Manual starts also make for good variation at the beginning of races and again just feels that bit more realistic waiting for the lights to go out.One area I am disappointed in is the difficulty options of the game. I find myself too quick for Expert difficulty but way too slow for Legend. It really feels like their should be a middle ground option between these two as I have seen many say the same.Presentation and graphics looks nice albeit the same as F1 2015. Bug fixes have been made since the game's release as well as improvements which suggests Codies are really listening to fans this year after taking their input in the game's design. Overall, F1 2016 is the best Formula 1 experience out there for me, and will keep you racing for a long time.8/10.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Great game, been looking for a good racing game for a while and saw this, i like f1 so i got it. It's great. The controls are good and you can talk to your race engineer with a microphone, though this can sometimes be iffy. The game features the creation of your own driver, allowing you to get a better feeling of imersion in the game as you are your own driver down to helmet patterns, driver number, name and the team you start off with. also features a seperate career if you prefer driving as your favourite drivers. Game runs well and so far (FPS is lowered in the paddock before sessions though, although that doesnt matter) i've only had 1 crash (of the game not the car) so far in the ammount of time i have played the game.The driving is also really good, it lets you customise almost every aspect of driving, allowing aids for anti locking breaks and traction control aswell as displaying the racing line if needed. The game also features complete customisation of the length of a race weekend, allowing full qualifying sessions, and even a full race where you do the number of laps done by the real drivers on a race weekend, though it allows this to be reduced to half of the race, a quarter or 5 lapts for people lacking that ammount of time. I can't comment on the improvements over F1 2015 as i have not played it, however i can say this is an extremely solid racing game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2016
												Well done Codemasters! You really stepped it up this year.Reviewed after around 13 hours of gameplay incuding a quick race at spa, 4 rounds of career mode (full qualifying, full practice, 50% race) and a few online sprint races + Beautiful Graphics, more realistic styling than F1 2015+ Good A.I, racing is slightly worse but they make many more strategy decision+ Safety Car + Virtual Safety Car+ More options for speaking to the engineer+ Multifunctional display is miles better than is previous games+ Very detailed R&D development + Good character models+ Characters are voiced well+ Commentators have more varied commentary+ Laptop function is cool+ Good testing programms+ More A.I difficulty settings+ Variable race strategies+ Improved damage model, including wheel tethers+ Personalised 10 year career mode+ Ability to upgrade your team so that it is improved on overall standing+ Multiplayer connection is greatly improved+ Manual starts+ Formation Lap+ Physics are much less arcadey than they where last year, much harder to drive+ Much better and more realistic kerb physics+ Very good wet weather driving physics+ Includes all 22 drivers, cars and liveries of the 2016 F1 season- Car sounds are a mixed bag: Honda sounds great, Mercedes sounds pretty horrific, Ferrari and Renault both sound ok- Sometimes the damage model is still too forgiving- Target times for practice programms are sometimes too high- A.I. are faster in qualifying than the race and even faster in practice- A.I. set some unrealistic times in practice and qualifying, for example being high up in a not so great car on the slower tire- My wheel (Logitech G27) is sometimes reset to 900 degrees during sessions for no reason- Online penalty system is still a mixed bag- Warming up tyres and brakes on the formation lap seems to be irrelevant because the game resets the grid fully before the race start- Car models seem a little off- Sound bugs when in a big group of cars- No classic contentAll in all this years F1 game is well worth a purchase for fans of the series and motorsport fans in general.9/10

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												F1 2016 is easily the best edition in the Codemasters F1 series that keeps pulling me back in to keep racing the way the previous titles couldn't. I mainly play sports career games, so a big welcome return in the player career mode where you can race as yourself amongst the field that was missing from 2015. The game allows you to somewhat design your own helmet, pick a number that isn't taken by the existing grid and a best-fit driver avatar before picking a team and getting the main game underway. It's obvious this is where Codemasters spent the time this year.Instead of breezing through practice, skipping straight to qualifying like days of old, you are now expected to earn research points via practice programmes that are spent to add updates to your car throughout the season. It is a requirement as the teams around you are continually developing their cars, so you need to too to keep pace. The programmes consist of tyre management, which provides you on tyre wear data for the race as well as research points, track aclimitisation and qualifying runs. They do a great job at making practice interesting and giving you tasks to do during practice helps with the immersiveness of the career.On a gameplay side, Codemasters have done a good job at portraying each car's strength, with the difference between say the Mercedes and Manor noticable, but not blindingly obvious. The handling of the cars feels good and overall the driving is solid. I found this not to be the case on a controller though, with the gamepad just not providing enough responsiveness to race quickly or competitively. It is good to see the safety car return too, this time fully controllable unlike previous versions as well as the new virtual safety car. Manual starts also make for good variation at the beginning of races and again just feels that bit more realistic waiting for the lights to go out.One area I am disappointed in is the difficulty options of the game. I find myself too quick for Expert difficulty but way too slow for Legend. It really feels like their should be a middle ground option between these two as I have seen many say the same.Presentation and graphics looks nice albeit the same as F1 2015. Bug fixes have been made since the game's release as well as improvements which suggests Codies are really listening to fans this year after taking their input in the game's design. Overall, F1 2016 is the best Formula 1 experience out there for me, and will keep you racing for a long time.8/10.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												I'm pretty impressed with it. I generally prefer racing games that fall on the more realistic simulation side of things like Assetto Corsa and Project Cars. (More Assetto Corsa these days). I was a bit worried about how F1 2016 would feel/handle and FFB. I just spent about 40 laps at Melbourne in time trial mode getting a feel for things and once i got FFB and controls setup it feels quite good to me. I was afraid Assetto may have spoiled me with the SF15/F138 they recently released but i think the F1 cars in this game are very good and on par with the Assetto models. I only tried expert mode with all assists off and it seems quite "realistic" (Well as realistic as i'll ever know.. given i'll never touch one of these cars IRL)I had some intermittent issues with steering initially...1st: i had to turn my wheel all the way to get the car to turn at all.. the ratio seemed way off and too slow. found the steering saturation option and bumped it to 75 which seemed to fix that.2nd: occasionally i'd have an issue where i had zero FFB and the saturation setting above wasnt working.. It seemed to go away after crashing into something. (Using a Fanatec CSW V2) Time will tell if this persists.I'm not a huge F1 fan but watch with a passive interest. This is my first game from the official F1 series but overall i think this game is very solid. Looking forward to the career options. I dunno if you'd call it a sim or arcade or simcade, but at this point I think the physics are very good and will it will provide a lot of fun and replay-ability.Graphics look very good and i'm glad to have some unique tracks that i dont have access to from any other games like COTA and Singapore.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												I've been playing this series for many years and I have to say they got a lot of things right this time.  The cars are fun to drive, and the AI seems pretty challenging for all types of drivers.  The tracks are great, and thank goodness Germany is back in the mix!  The enhanced menu for making changes to the car while driving is GREAT.For the most fun, career is the way to go.  My only complaints about career mode are 1. The tedious repetition of the laptop, phone calls, and challengers (we should be able to pick our rivals with more XP given for more difficult rivals) 2. There is no bonus R&D given for winning the championship !?!The game is fun, I use the XBOX 360 controller and it seems to work well.All in all, this is the one F1 game I would recommend to anyone looking for a fun racing game ***If you have a very powerful computer***

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												Credit where credit is due - after several poor efforts from F1 2014 and 2015 and much criticsm, Codemasters have taken everything that was great about F1 2013, added significant polish and then provided a Career mode that at this early stage seems to be one that will keep me interested for many weeks and months to come.I have no doubt there are bugs and glitches to be found - although I have yet to find them - but I think Codemasters deserve huge praise for this effort. There are so mnay nice touches that add to the feeling that this is game that has been nurtured and enhanced for far longer than a year. It made me chuckle when I - driving as Lewis Hamilton - ran Nico off the road and Lewis had the audacity to give him an angry hand gesture. A little thing but in conjunction with all of the additions to this game it just reinforces the feeling that this is a quality product.It is still very early days so I'm sure there is a lot more for me to discover - good and bad - but so far my only issue is the force feedback on my Logitech Force GT. I daresay the various forums will find settings and solutions in the coming days but so far, all I can feel is an annoyingly harsh rattle as if I was hitting a speedbump at speed, periodically around the track. Other than that, my first experiences with this game have been delightfully, surprisingly positive.

Graphics: ★★★★★Performance & stability: ★★★☆☆Sound: ★★★★★Gameplay: ★★★★☆Story (Career Mode): ★★★★★Game modes & extra content: ★★★★☆Multiplayer: ★★★☆☆OVERALL: 8.29 / 10Notes:- slightly improved graphics- slightly improved sound- slightly improved physics- Career Mode returned- Safety Car returned- Virtual Safety Car- formation lap- manual starts- throttle input very difficult to modulate- driving with assists is faster & more consistent in most scenarios- performance issues - severe framerate drops at specific circuits- still no Scenario Mode- still no split-screen mode- still no ranking system in Multiplayer Mode- penalty system still very poor- still many players crashing into other on purpose

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												Last year I wrote a really scathing review for F1 2015, which I felt was not just the worst codies F1 game but also just the worst AAA F1 game I've ever played. I had my doubts that this one would be better even with codemaster's saying they knew they got it wrong and making a survey for the fans about what features they wanted months before it came out but they have actually pulled it off. They went from 2015 being the worst F1 game I've ever played, to 2016 being the best one I've ever played. The customization options are better, the driving is more fun, practice is actually engaging and now with the new way it allows you to earn R&D points to develop your car the career mode is better than ever. Online still has lots of the usual issues with casual online games but seems to be pretty good, not tried it for league racing though just casuals so no idea how well it will hold up when you aren't playing with random people who can just crash you and leave the game, probably a lot better. Overall I definitely recommend this game, the most fun and engaging F1 game yet.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												Last year I wrote a really scathing review for F1 2015, which I felt was not just the worst codies F1 game but also just the worst AAA F1 game I've ever played. I had my doubts that this one would be better even with codemaster's saying they knew they got it wrong and making a survey for the fans about what features they wanted months before it came out but they have actually pulled it off. They went from 2015 being the worst F1 game I've ever played, to 2016 being the best one I've ever played. The customization options are better, the driving is more fun, practice is actually engaging and now with the new way it allows you to earn R&D points to develop your car the career mode is better than ever. Online still has lots of the usual issues with casual online games but seems to be pretty good, not tried it for league racing though just casuals so no idea how well it will hold up when you aren't playing with random people who can just crash you and leave the game, probably a lot better. Overall I definitely recommend this game, the most fun and engaging F1 game yet.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												First Codemasters F1 game I've bought since 2013 having been disappointed by a glitchy throttle and force feedback (G27) and physics that weren't at all believable (I'm pretty sure with no TCs I should be able to wheel spin off the line...).Well, what a revelation 2016 has turned out to be! Rear tyres that want to light up, believable and predictable handling, stunning graphics and a game that truly captures the atmosphere of F1 (your team even deploys pit boards!). For me the handling is the star of the show. It may not be a full on sim like Assetto Corsa, but it rewards accurate driving whilst still being a little forgiving.The career mode is really nice, with programs to run in practice to hone your skills and the set up whilst earning development points. I can see myself putting in many hours to win the WDC with Manor!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												I want two things from racing games: Realistic simulation and Exciting races. This game perfectly fufills the simulation aspect. The car feels powerful, and it's thrilling to push it to its limit. Coming into corners at 210 mph, slamming on the brakes, then speeding up again is an unreal experience. As for races, they are generally great, but not always. An example of a great one was when I was racing in Russia. There were 7 laps remaining and I was 10 seconds behind Vettel. I was gaining by 1.3 seconds a lap, and it was intense. I eventually caught up and passed him on the penultimate corner. The race was exciting and everything I want from a game. Unfortunately this is not always the case. Many times I've just got caught in a position with a 10 second gap ahead and behind. This creates a boring race that is more of a chore than a joy to complete.Despite sometimes encountering a boring race, F1 2016 fufills everything I want from an F1 game.

content:
Posted: March 28
												Let me start off by saying i am a huge f1 fan and have been playing f1 games since 2003. Im pleased to say this game is a huge improvement on all the earlier games and is by far the best in the series. Pros : Graphics are stunning, Being able to develop your car in career mode is a great feature although not completely perfect, damage model is a large step up with simulation damage being realistic, Handling is well done and fairly easy to get used to, Voice control feature is easy to use and very helpful.   Cons: Modding is very difficult, Ai can be reckless and sometimes tries to overtake when there is no spot to overtake, Overall fully recommend this game

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												Annual sports franchises are difficult to know when to jump in. Have they just update the drivers and car liveries, have they broken what worked before or worst of all have they stripped out all but the most basic features.F1 2016 takes the promise of a next-gen F1 game that 2015 failed to deliver and improves in almost every way.I'm not an online racer so career mode is where it is at for me. This is not only back but has been seriously upgraded. Teams can now be developed so seasons do vary with Mercedes not always staying on top. As part of this they have managed to make one of the most skipped parts of the game, practice sessions, now mean something as this is where you can earn upgrade points. The challenges in the sessions make sense, are fun and teach you about the course and an F1 car.None of this would matter if the racing wasn't up to scratch but Codemasters have made it very fun to race. The cars handle as you would expect with the margin between sublime cornering and spinning out of control so close. The game maintains it's excellent assists systems which you can dial back as you gain more experience someone just starting out can find their balance. I tend to race with a controller and I've never felt like I get less of an experience.Finally it seems this year Codemasters are really pushing this game to be as good as it can be. I've already seen 2 changes to the game that I expected not to see till 2017. Lots of people were finding there was too big a gap between 2 difficulties so Codemasters introduced a new level to bridge the gap.So in summary this is one of the great years for this annual franchise. Maybe next year will be even better but I don't think you can go wrong jumping in this year.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
												I've been playing F1 games and simulations all the way back to Grand Prix and Grand Prix 2. That being said I always look forward to a new game that tries to bring you that much more closer to the real life of a Formula 1 driver, and that much closer to realism. Every year since they got the rights I want to like Codemasters' effort into bringing me that experience and every year I get disappointed. It's not the game itself it's the 'effort'. Bugs, always. Lack of logic, always. They always seem to be their own worst enemy when developing these games. Don't LikeWet weather is better but still the game engine lacks the logic to know when it is wet and safe enough to run dry tires. If water is splashing up, it is NOT safe for dry slicks. My first wet race I was so excited then as the track (presumably) started to dry the AI switched to drys with mist still coming off my intermediates. WTF.The hospitality scenes. I get it, you want to make us feel like racing drivers but the whole cell phone, manager and engineer bit is just repetitive and annoying. Give me a first person view and be able to walk around the area, interact with people on my own for more immersion. Maybe I can call my manager and see if any teams are hiring (if i want to move). Maybe I can interact with the engineers to get more info from them on how to set up the car.No practice starts or focus on starts. Way too easy to get these cars off the line. There should be more focus on practicing your starts and if you don't get it right your car goes nowhere on the start.Pit stops need more interaction from the driver. Stopping long, short or leaving early/too late.I won't comment on my own experiences with my video card (can't overclock, crashes to desktop) because I think that is unfair given that is pretty much subjective.My likesDrivability is pretty 'arcade'. In my opinion Assetto Corsa or iRacing will get you to closer to the real feel of these cars sliding around BUT I like how forgiving they are even with TC off and using a gamepad. Progression is fun and doesn't make you feel like a losing battle as in previous years. In McLaren I am in the top 10 which by all means is not realistic but still it's your own adventure.Damage is much better and fun that it is easier to destroy your car because that's just how it really is.Ai is a lot more fun to race with.Even though I commented above about the weather dynamics and 'logic' around it,  it is much much more improved. The water drips off the mirrors and reacts so much nicer then anything else I've played.---I probably could talk so much more about this game. In the end if you love F1 then yeah I think it's ok. If you aren't, I still think this game will give you a good experience into the sport.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												Introduction:If you are watching F1 grand prix including the practice sessions, and qualifying sessions and allways wanted to be in the shoes of some of the drivers from this year or in the future, this game will suit you. Carreer mode:F1 2016 includes all of the drivers and teams from 2016, and have a deep and engaging carreer mode lasting 10 years/sessions from 2016-2026 . In the carrer mode you can choose your tire strategy for each race and customize your cars in alot of ways to help you beat the opponents in the practice sessions and qualifying. Practice sessions:The practice sessions have alot of detail, including team-objectives where you learn how to save your tires and how to drive on the apex of the circuits. After you have completed the team-objectives you will earn funds, which you can use on various parts of the car f.ex. a better engine, more optimized fuel-systems , chasis-development etc.Race:After you have completed both the practice sessions and the qualification, you can choose to run a track parade, where you can increase the temperature of the tires.The AI cars race are very good, and have been improved from 2015, so f.ex. you will have less accidents with other AI-cars at the start of the race. There are 7 difficult levels you can choose from for the AI cars: "very easy" to "ultimate".Graphics: 95 /100The graphics of F1 2016 is improved from the earlier version and includes a full time-of-day, so you can f.ex. see the sun go down and lights turn on. The game includes dynamic weather effects, so you will have to change tires in mid-race if it's raining. The tracks have alot of detail and have more details than F1 2015.Sound: 85 / 100Sound is very nice with alot of details, like the sound of rain on the hood, the abillity to hear the other F1 cars engines both on track and in pit etc. The cars could have a better engine sound though.Performance: 95 / 100On my old Phenom 955 with 8gb of ram and a Nvidia GTX 960 I have around 39 fps with ultra settings and I haven't noticed any lag like there was in F1 2015.Overall: 92 /100The best Formula One game I have ever played!

Posted: August 19, 2016
												I was looking forward to F1 2016 and boy it's good!  Graphics are more polished than F1 2015  Career mode is back with a bang. Best of the series so far.  Performance is pretty good on a 970 gtx. Getting 60 fps on ultra 1080p and 110+ fps on high with no observable difference in quality  Time of day editor is a welcome addition. Really fun playing singapore in the day time  Learning curve is really steep, especially with a pad. Struggling to gain traction out of corners with tc off. F1 2015 was easy to pick up and play but this one really requires practise and concentration  Car audios are much better than 2015. The McLaren sounds the best.  There are some audio bugs that I faced with a lot of cars on the grid around me. It sounded like the audio from the ai cars are choppy  Kerbs and grass are way more slippery. No more throwing the car over the corners, you will spin out!  AI are very similar to F1 2015. I didn't observe much of a difference in behaviour  Simulation damage..nuff saidF1 from codemasters is no longer arcarde. If you want a game to pick up and play, go for F1 2015. F1 2016 are for those who like to see wheel tethers (a lot! :D)

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												F1 2016 is a great F1 game. Capitalising on the great handling + graphics combination produced the year prior, Codemasters spent the last year making improvements such as adding a thrilling and customisable career mode, improving online net code to a pleasant level, and perfecting what they had already done well. It's a game for all abilities, whether this is your first racer or you are a real life motorsport driver, you can blend the ai difficulties and assists to any level to utilise the generally realistic yet pick-up-and-playable handling model. It's not perfect as I'm almost making it out to be, but I'm really looking forward to the next release from a developer that's proved it knows what it's doing now.My personal experience has been slightly altered by having a graphics card driver problem in my first months of ownership which meant quick race was the only working mode, and also with suddenly receiving every Codemasters game I've been playing with them a lot recently too. I definitely should have more hours on this than I do!(Side note: I am able to run the game at 45-55 FPS on medium settings w/ an i7 and 750Ti so it isn't too hard to run either!)Pros:Realistic and rewarding handlingGreat, and quite easy to run, graphicsLow grip situations improved (grass on tyres, wet conditions, kerbs etc.)Intriguing career modeEasy to pick-up-and-play with assistsDecent/good online qualityBest AI yet (still room for improvement though!)Minimal glitchesVastly improved damage system w/ tethers and simulation settingsCons:Unrealistic/over-realistic in some situations (grass on tyres feels like being on a wet track on dry tyres, save me!)Pad steering is IMPOSSIBLE to be smooth (If Codies could bring back the slightest steering assist to all pad players to help situations where wheel is completely OP then that'd be appreciated)Not massively moddableOP tyre glitch (look up online if you don't understand what it is)A few other little things possiblyOverall, a big recommend, even if £40 is a bit steep it'll be about half that in the sales so do capitalise on it if you can!

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												Video review is available here: 


YouTube™ Video: F1 2016 - The ultimate F1 game? 

			Views: 100		

			F1 2016 is Codemasters' 8th iteration of a Formula 1 game, but is this the ultimate F1 game?		

F1 2016 marks Codemasters' 8th iteration of the Formula 1 title, if you include F1 2009 which bizarrely only released on the Wii. After 8 iterations has Codemasters finally made the perfect Formula 1 game?This is so far the best Codemasters F1 game to date. I had a few issues with crash to desktop where the game would just close or minimise, but on the other hand I got several hours at a time without any such issues. I also had an issue with not being able to save my progress, or even start the game because it said C drive didn't have enough space (why this was an issue, I don't know, since the game is saved to a different drive with over half a terabyte of space) but after verifying the game files and rebooting my system (and uninstalling a few megabytes worth of programs), the game seems happy again (time will tell if the crash to desktop issue returns). Overall the game runs great at a considerably higher framerate than the previous titles pushing the 100s in places and otherwise sitting at 90 fps on high settings. I'm using a GTX 780 at 1080p and the game defaulted to high settings, and on max it should give a perfectly acceptable 60 fps, so if you have a 980 like the game recommends you should get an even better experience.Graphics are improved and the attention to the real sport is great. They've successfully 'game-ified' F1 and gotten across the more important technical parts of the sport. Codemasters has made changes to the Free Practice modes and have refined the free practice objectives. Each objective you meet gives you points to upgrade your car during the season and for me, this makes free practice worth doing again. For example, the tyre wear test teaches you how to go faster and preserve your tyres. You'll find yourself improving lap after lap and yet your tyre wear will get progressively better as your driving style becomes smoother. Track acclimatisation is something else they've put in. You get a series of gates to go through around the track and the faster and more accurately you pass through them the higher your score and the more development points you get. This not only teaches you to go fast, but also correct car positioning. Your personal tyre wear data can be used to create your pit strategy during the race which is great. Speaking of pit strategies, the game can now suggest new strategies on the fly depending on what's happening in the race so it's just like the real sport. On top of all that, if that wasn't enough, tiny differences like fuel load and tyre wear make a huge difference to the handling.Development points aren't just restricted to Free Practice. Development points are up for grabs all the way through a career mode weekend, be it for meeting a team objective, completing a certain number of laps in a session, beating your rival or taking home the big prize of a race win. Your performance not only nets you development points, but affects your standing within the team on the way to the coveted number one driver. The Development Points you earn act as an R&D currency, so the better you perform, the more points you have and the faster you  can get those sweet R&D upgrades. You get to choose to the development of your team in Career Mode and as your on track performance ties into so many different things, it's important to get out there and let your driving do the talking. With a 10 season career mode you can really stamp your authority within the team.Career mode boasts a leader board section which compares you against other players, based on the points you have earned so the competitive types should get their kick out of that.AI also suffer incidents, penalties and mechanical failures which should make the racing more interesting and unpredictable (having spent almost all my time online and only just starting career mode I can't say how much it affects races and can't comment too much on AI race craft). I'm just getting stuck into the career mode and so far, so good, everything you'd expect is present, including the Safety and Virtual Safety Car, which so far, are bug free. In races, blue flag AI works as it should, unlike some of the previous titles and I had little trouble getting past in the quick races I did. The safety car is here too along with formation laps and these are all bug free and working as intended so far. The only thing I would say is on the formation lap, the AI is too fast. They will go at racing speed off the line and will overtake you if you decide to slow down to do any tyre warming. I haven't seen them attempt to do any so far, but this will be different in career mode.The game also boasts support for custom drivers now, where you pick what you look like, your number, name, three letter abbreviation etc. and while this is a great addition, it would have been nice to see some more diversity in the faces (if you know what I'm saying). This feature could be further improved by letting the player choose an audio name. Other games from Codemasters allow it, so why not here? If this was allowed the commentators and pit crew could address you by name rather than 'a *car name here*'Online is fully featured, but unfortunately sees the return of hopper lobbies for sprint races. It would have been nice to have a session list like the custom races have as too often, I leave a lobby, search for a new one and get dropped back in the same lobby. Custom sessions have no such issue as the game provides a session browser so you can make informed decisions on which lobby to join. Players online are as you'd expect in any racing game and it's a shame nothing is being done (e.g. harsher penalties and safeguards such as ghosting blue flagged opponents) to kerb negative behaviour as it ruins what could be an amazing experience.Sound design is near perfect, with the engines sounding that little bit different to each other and the turbo whine (which some may find annoying) coming through on top. Coupled with a expanded pit radio voice commands, this is a very immersive title. The Xbox One controller is supported and the cars handle brilliantly on there, especially when you have a custom setup applied. The cars are tricky to handle and you can lose the back end incredibly easily if you're not careful. Setups see the addition of Steam Workshop support. You can browse the workshop at the start of a session or race and download a setup straight into your game for use there and then. This brilliant addition means, if you're like me, and don't want to spend a long time setting the car up, you can grab one from the workshop and be on your way.  So far, F1 2016 is a great game. I could go on as there's so much more to this game than you're willing to read. It takes the sport of Formula 1 and faithfully recreates and game-ifies it in what seems to be this series' Dirt Rally moment. It brings in features fans have been asking for, makes newcomers welcome with its video tutorials and refines old features with a level of polish we haven't seen from this series in a long time. Purists can argue that the lack of a Young Driver Test is a big negative, but honestly it's removing features like that which allow me to jump into a front running team in my first season. Provided you're not unlucky like I am when it comes to your games working properly, F1 2016 shouldn't disappoint.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
Product received for free
												The game features an enhanced career mode that takes place over ten seasons. Specific race goals are dependent on the strength of the team, and driver rivalries develop over time. A very neat feature is practice objectives: performing specific tests (like learning the track, conserving tires, or going on a qualifying run) will earn research points that can be spent on upgrading car parts. It is a welcome feature that gives a purpose to practice other than simply turning laps. In addition to the career mode, single seasons, quick races, time trials, and online multiplayer with full twenty-two car fields are available. A number of minor new features (the Azerbaijan street circuit, new Haas team, a formation lap, manual race starts, manual pitting, and the safety car) are also added for this year’s version. Racing physics are plausible, including tire wear, handling, and damage. Driving assists can be adjusted to support a wide range of player abilities, and flashbacks can be used to rewind time if needed. AI drivers are appropriately aggressive. F1 2016 is a slick, feature-complete simulation perfect for the racing aficionado. 


YouTube™ Video: F1 2016 Gameplay Review

Posted: February 11
TL/DR REVIEWIn my opinion this is easily the best F1 game in the codemasters era. Don't expect a hardcore simulation, because it's clearly not. I play the game with a wheel, which enhances the experience greatly. The physics are not hyper realistic, but with all assists off (except for TC on medium) the game is realistic enough to suspend my disbelief. As with any (mainstream) racing game you shouldn't expect clean racing in online public lobbies. I spend most of my time in the time trial and the career mode, which are both very entertaining.Final noteThis is not an in depth or complete review of the game. It simply sums up my experience with the game in an effort to help you make a more informed purchasing decision.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												After around 30+ hours on F1 2016 I have to say this:Whilst I agree with every aspect of the gameplay excitement and its overall presentation, immersion and surroundings, I have to say I am somewhat disappointed with the graphics actually. It's a love hate-relationship there. Everything closeup looks really good-the lighting is fabulous, but everything further away becomes a blurry mess. The fuzzyness of the cutout/paste mechanics are atrocious. The lack of PROPER multi-sampling or super sampling AA options compounds this even further. Line markings in the distance are such a jaggedy-jag-jag, that it reminds me of the 90ies for crying out loud. And not to mention, that there is no SLI/Crossfire(?) support. WTF? 2016-no SLI support? Get out! 'And what about FFB Luds?'- 'edited' A plus point after some tinkering. Unlike other titles FFB is actually perfect out of the box and just requires some proper dampening setup in the according controller driver and you can truly feel the lateral movements and weightshifts of the car. Quite impressive. AMS and RRE feel a little more involving overall still, but this title has the best dampening FFB impression, which helps wet races immensely, a lot of fun. For me the game is fantastic to play, but keep in mind I enjoyed GP2 as well and heck it did not look anywhere nearly as good as this. However, if this game would use the engine of F1 2014 it would be the final word in F1 simulations IMO and they would not need to make another. So yeah - I LOVE THIS GAME, but am a little disappointed to see the OVERALL rather lackluster effect-grabbing, technically underwhelming graphics of this game. Gameplay/Immersion: 10/10 (updated to MAX after I truly played multiplayer-fantastic!)Sound: 8/10Graphics: 5/10FFB: 8/10 (updated -> had some minor brain underpowering setting it up correctly.)Overall(based on above): 31/40 - 77.5%I recommend this game for the gameplay/the options/the adjustability/the sheer racing immersion and excitement. Again I am just disappointed, because I thought the game engine is two steps forwards and one big step backwards.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												This is a light hearted review, nothing to be taken to seriously but before I get into that, I would fully suggest buying this game if you're a F1 fan, I've spent 8 hours in total in the game and I've only just completed the first GP, FP1 and the rest actually mean something now and the AI are somewhat competent enough to respond to your moves. Now for the things that amused me.Seriously now though, within the first 4 laps of race day Lewis pinched me off track to overtake resulting in a nasty 720 spin and a puncture, didn't even get a penalty! (Realism, eh!? ;) )"Shut up Jeff!" totally works too, never had more fun asking for more updates and then telling him to shut up half a lap later, made the straights a little bit more entertaining when I wasn't close enough to creep up the inside of the car ahead. Lewis didn't get 1st place on the podium yet still jumped around and celebrated, that's certainly a minus in the realism points... (Lewis gets some flak in this review, before you jump at me though I'm not an out and out hater of Lewis) Oh and yeah, Max double blocked me...Either codies have been hard at work or just coincidence but I had to laugh. Great game, very much an improvement over all the others.

												I have owned all the F1 games from codemasters since 2012, and after the big disappointment last year with F1 2015 this years F1 2016 is actually the best one i have played so far. Career mode is here again and its very motivating to play and has a fair learning curve with the training modes and achievements. Race strategies tire management is far more easy to handle, than in the previous games. Best thing happened at my first career race in australia when i lost part of my front wing and had to pit just 2 rounds after i switched tires. The box crew automatically suggests new strategies to switch tires again in different order. Worked pretty well!Graphics are also better than last year. Running smooth on my 970 GTX in 1920x1200 with ultra details.Buy it!

												Came over from 2013. First thing I noticed was reduced difficultly with assists and Easy AI is easy enough for even the most spoiled participation trophy receiving millenials. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												I haven't bought an F1 game since F1 2012. I felt that they generally started to follow a formula (lolpun) and got into somewhat of a rut.I'm happy to say that this one completely smashes it out of the park. Absolutely everywhere where F1 has stumbled in the past has finally been addressed. For instance, the feeling that you were never really driving other cars during qualifying, and that it was all faked to give the illusion of a close session. All that is gone. You can now watch your AI competitors via their onboard cameras whilst parked in the pitlane.The AI feels consistent through each round of the calendar too. In previous years I would find that I would struggle to qualify in Australia, but be pole position in Bahrain. Now it feels that over the year they stay competitive. From what I am hearing too, the AI seems to pose quite a challenge. I'm only playing on Hard AI difficulty right now, but I feel like I might be able to put it up a notch soon.I think my new favourite feature for this particular outing of this franchise though, is the practice sessions. They finally feel worth doing. The track acclimatization and tyre wear tests make practice feel meaningful.I recommend anyone who has already bought the game to put the damage up from "Full" to "Simulation", (it makes no sense to me that there is a setting above full but whatever). Simulation tends to lead to more AI faults and crashes leading to two safety cars so far, one real and one virtual, but they all add to the excitement of each race. This makes the damage particuarly unforgiving however, leading to more than a few tyres hanging on by their tethers, (which looks awesome by the way).All in all, this is their best yet, and I really think this is up there with the great Geoff Crammond Grand Prix 4. I really recommend you give it a go.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												10/10.Well, what can I say. After many years of feeling 'bored' with F1 games, they finaly went and hit the nail on the head with this one. Everything we asked for; formation lap, safety car, career mode, helmet customization  has all been added. But not only have they been added, they've been done correctly and not just 'thrown' in. Here's my opinion on different parts of the game.Career Mode:What can I say. I was very excited and eager to start. I was first faced with Character customization, which was simple and yet efficient. Then it was the team selection, Which I'm glad you can choose any team as it makes it more 'personal' rather than being forced your Path.R&D:As we know it, Research & Development was kind of the weakness in the past years. But this time, it brings a whole new meaning, not only do you improve. Other teams improve and even some don't. But...I honestly think R&D is too easy & too early. In my 1st season with Haas & into the 14th race. Toro Rosso was already 3rd Fastest, Which seemed a little unrealistic. But other than that, it's perfect.Safety & Virtual Safety Car:Finaly. it's back! F1 2015 felt rushed without the safety car, although the Graphics was massively improved from 2014 and some will even argue they're still the best to this day for CM. With it completely been re-done, it feels much better. Although at times, it doesn't come out when it should and it comes out when it shouldn't. In my 2 seasons I've only had 1 VSC, so other than it being rare. I can't really give feedback other than it worked great when it did happen.But yeah that's it. The Game is great again. Thanks.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
												Second review hype!I am a long time racing fan. I've played the crap out of GT4 & GT5, and then the first few F1 Games. I played a lot of 2010 & 2011, but not as much as 2013. By far my favourite code masters game.I tried to like the previous two titles (2015 & 2014) but they were both rushed. 2014 to me felt like a rehash of 2013 with the 2014 cars and content, and 2015 felt like more a demo game engine then an actual game.This game is what 2015 should of been. 2015 laid the foundation for this wonderful game to be great, and I was really hoping code masters would publish a game that did these new V6 cars justice, and they really have. The game works great on my PC, and shows its technical advanced over the previous titles in terms of graphics and handling. I race with a G27 and triple screen setup, (980ti, 4930k, 16gb ram). This is what 2015 laid the foundation for. I have not had any crashes or noticeable bugs, and the game runs smoothly without frame drops.But they went above and beyond, the practice sessions now give me something to do instead of feeling like I'm going around and around without benefit. The cars feel great, I'm driving a manor and it feels like it should, not as well balanced as the top tier cars and definitely slower. I'm playing on hard as I used to play on pro back in 2013, and the game feels challenging but rewarding, I don't actually care that I come close to last because of the fun I'm actually having driving the car. The immersion is fantastic, getting drifty and ant to commentate as well as the formation lap, voice control and pre-race all make me feel like I'm driving in a real race weekend.The out of car stuff blows me away, the r&d, the new 'agent' and the rivalry really pull me into this game like GT5 did so many years ago, and while I can't just buy a new car like I did in that, I'm damn well committed to developing this manor into a race winning team. 10/10 would buy again.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												Pretty good so far, there are some issues however. The career doesn't save properly if you don't press advance and you quit. My save got pretty muddled up as I qualified last but got placed in 14th on the grid for the race I had to redo. Speaking of qualifying, the qualifying pace of the AI seems way too high compared to their race pace. I generally qualify about 2 seconds off my team mate whether I have assists on or off (I generally have them off appart from ABS), but in the race my team mate is always beaten by me either by me finishing higher or beacuse my sector times and best lap was way quicker and sometimes both. There also seems to be a flashback issue where in some instances it makes the tires feel like you're driving on ice. The career home section also lags like crazy dipping down to 15-20fps on my 960M (might just be mobile chips) but the races generally hover around 50 fps on a mix of high and medium settings (1080p).There are a bunch of good things though; The career mode is the best it has ever been from my experience with the RnD progression system and revamped rival system. Having VSC and Saftey Cars is amazing and the manual starts are really fun to do. The formation lap gets kinda boring however in my opinion. The multiplayer is back to what it used to be somewhat and playing on a near maxed out lobby was the most fun I've had in F1 for a long time. Overall it feels like a much more polished version of F1 2015 with the 2016 liveries, greater longevity due to the revamped career mode and better multiplayer.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												Finally we have a decent F1 game.I played last years version on the PS4 and it was lamentable. This years PC version is rather good. I am playing at 4k with everything maxed on on a 58inch panel and the game runs like a dream. Framerate is very smooth and it pulls infrequently. I suspect that is a bug that will be fixed. The audio gets scrambled at the same time. But this only happens for a second or two.The game looks good. Maybe the trees and stands could look a bit more lifelike.Career mode is much improved from 2014 version. Finally we can have a shorter race. I wont do 15 lapsas its too time consuming and boring. I play with the 360 gamepad and its fine. I dont get any lag.I won't do multiplayer anymore. Last year on ps4 it was better as all the other players were in ghost cars. Most frustrating for mentally unstable gamers who like to ruin games by running everyone off the road. A big problem once again is collision detection. Its awful as usual. For a simulation its perplexing why the AI is so acrade like.Overall the is an excellent game and most addictive.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												Well I had low expectations for this after the dismal product that was F1-2015. But this title nailed it. Yes its not a serious sim. But it has enough sim like qualities to make hardcore sim racers happy. It also has enough assists to help arcade racers too. The game looks familiar yet all new. The handling model is better than expected. I have to say that this may be the best F1 title from codies yet. I still think the colors in my modded version of 2010 look more real (even with the sweetFX enabled it looks a but cartoony) but this has all the features that have been asked for. The pit boards are near impossible to read but who cares. The fact that they pop over the wall while driving by is a cool touch.   I love the addition of the safety car (back finally) and the VSC. Weather and opponent updated from the crew are actually useful for once. The new tracks look like they should, and seem to race how they look on tv. I am most impressed with the garage and new on the fly menu options, for diff settings and wing repairs if needed. I also like the formation lap and manual start/pitstop control... nice touches.Performance wise it runs smooth as silk on my system. I have it DSR'ed in the nvidia control panel and maxed out in game. I have frame rates locked at 60 and theres no hint of a thought of a slowdown.  The only thing id like to see added is support for my track IR. Other than that its worth a buy. Its not a disappointment for once! This may finally be the F1 game that we have been asking for.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												Codemasters has been making F1 vidgames since 2009, now, in their 8th installation, I believe they've gotten a step closer to perfection. I have played every F1 game, but I only really liked 2013 (the V8s) and 2016. This game is rad -- the best one yet.  Category Rating (of 5) Reasoning   Graphics 4.5/5 Awesome variety of settings, didn't get perfect 5 because some textures are weak on the side of the track. The game is easy to optimize for a specific setup.   Sound 9/10 The car sounds are amazing and so faithful to the real thing. From the turbo whine and wheel spin to crashes, and rain starts, the sounds are AMAZING. Also, the various manufacturers' cars sound different from each other -- especially when braking (McLaren-Honda sounds way different from the Force India, for example -- S/O to  ♥♥♥♥♥ Tassles ).   Music 4/5 Idk, I turned it down, so should you. Engines are more important.   Cinematics 3.5/5 The intro stuff is amazing, but the career cut scenes, while beautiful in the background, leave something to be desired in the face department. For a racing game though? Top notch.   Story 5/5 A little spice and variety with contract changes, engineering stuff, and goals. Not obtrusive, but present and fun.   Content 5/5 Great variety for a racing game. Fun career, fast quick race mode, and simple multiplayer.   Gameplay/Controls 5/5 Simple, refined gameplay and controls. Great on controller, perfect on racing wheel. Easy to learn, difficult to master. They've added manual starts, formation laps, dynamic weather (get good at rain racing), and some other crud. The crashes are improved and more realistic. The AI is weak on the bottom 3 settings, casual on the middle one, and a good challenge on the final 3 -- you'll adapt. The upgrade system is way cool and encourages thoughtful and engaging play through the entire F1 weekend.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												7/10Even if you don't like open wheel racing, this is the best circuit racing game you can get on Steam.The things that are expected to be good, such as the racing physics, driver AI, and the overall simulation are all top notch. The racing itself may not be completely realistic, but this is a game, so compromises must be made to include things such as the Multi Function Display in order to remove frustration and improve enjoyment.While the game on the track might as well be perfection, the game outside of the racing could use a little work. Many cutscenes are locked at 30FPS, which can be jarring for users using a non standard refresh rate monitor. The Career mode's r&d programme allows you to develop your car at an unrealistically fast rate and car development is carried into the next season. Finally, I am disappointed in the lack of female driver avatars. Since there is no voice acting for the drivers, I don't see why there are no female avatars that would have made the game feel more inclusive.In general, the racing in this game is near perfect, but any other F1 fan can tell you there is more to Formula One and racing than what happens on the tarmac. I hope Codemasters can remove or ameloirate the faults in upcoming patches, which have already significantly improved the game.

												1st of all The game was extremly well optimised here (PRECISE HERE), i have a solid 60FPS with everything between HIGH/ULTRA (x16MSAA), 1080pRIG:i5-4570 @ 3.20GHz8GB of RAMGTX 1060 (8GB)Game install on HDDAbout the game, I expected nothing from so I am pleasantly surprised to see the quality of F1 2016.Driving is pleasant, easy but tricky once some aids disabled :) The career mode was pretty great tbh, i enjoy it so well ! Posted: August 19, 2016
												AI overly aggressive - I have had cars crash into me 5-10 times per race - usually on DRS zone. While i was on a racing line. With good pace. Not blocking.Again, difficulty is total BS. Either 2 seconds too fast or 2 seconds too slow.Career mode gets real old real soon. Either its driving through checkpoints, saving tires (usually you only need to look out for a corner or two where tyres heat up drastically for some reason) or a fast lap. That’s it. None of it is difficult.Forget the immersion. There is none. If you've seen the trailer, you've seen it all. A manager and an engineer. with 1 - 2 sentences each.Unlike in real life, sky commentators are unimaginative and repetitive. I've stopped listening to them after 3-4 races.Still no tutorial on how to set-up the car.Where is ERS?I'm still recommending it. Just because 2015 was total crap. Don’t get fooled.  This is not a good game. For f1 fans only.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												So, i've been away from PC driving sims for some time.  Largely because i got rid of my wheel, and also because every sim I've tried in recent history has had inferior driving 'feel' to the gran turismo series on the playstation when played with a controller.F1 2016 feels 'right' to drive.  I'm using a 360 controller and feel that i can do with the car what i want, and handling feels like it should, given that i have never driven F1 before, the physics seem feasible.The AI is particularly good, and a vast improvement on anything i've played before.  Out brake a rival into a corner for example, and they will give room and try to cut back, rather than just plow into you or back way off like in other games.  There's actually some semblance of intelligence there, rather than just sitting on line.Recommended.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												So, i've been away from PC driving sims for some time.  Largely because i got rid of my wheel, and also because every sim I've tried in recent history has had inferior driving 'feel' to the gran turismo series on the playstation when played with a controller.F1 2016 feels 'right' to drive.  I'm using a 360 controller and feel that i can do with the car what i want, and handling feels like it should, given that i have never driven F1 before, the physics seem feasible.The AI is particularly good, and a vast improvement on anything i've played before.  Out brake a rival into a corner for example, and they will give room and try to cut back, rather than just plow into you or back way off like in other games.  There's actually some semblance of intelligence there, rather than just sitting on line.Recommended.
